Name: Museum: The Archaeologists
Description:
The expansion adds an extra step to the game: in order to exhibit precious artefacts in their Museums, our Curators will now need to send their agents out into the world to bring them back first!

Players will have to choose which Continents to send their archaeologists to carefully, as funding expeditions doesn’t come cheap. However, if you don’t have any agents present, you can’t bring objects back from that Continent ! Unless of course, you can convince one of your competitor’s staff to lend a hand…

So how does it work ? The expansion’s board has spaces for each Continent, on which you can place your agent meeples to symbolize expeditions that you are sending out. Each player starts with one agent that they can place on any Continent they wish for free. Once you have an agent on site, you can bring objects back from that Continent as normal during the Exploration phase. If you have no agent on a particular Continent, but another player does, you can pay them 1 Prestige point to use their staff to do the work for you. If there are no agents present on that Continent, then you can’t bring anything back at all !

You can also pay extra to send additional archaeologists to a given Continent. If you do so, you gain additional bonuses, such as extra Prestige points when you draw a card. Each additional agent you send out to the same Continent costs more than the last. However, if you are the first to develop a full network of 3 agents, you gain a considerable bonus ! The second player to do so also gets a (smaller) bonus.

—description from the publisher

Name: Museum: Kickstarter Edition
Description:
This entry is for the Kickstarter edition of Museum.  Packaged inside are several expansions that are not contained in the retail release:


     The Crystal Skulls expansion, which adds 12 Crystal Skull cards which can be shuffled into the artifacts and when collected can either be played as a regular artifact or can be sold to a special 'Crystal Skull Collector' for many points.
     The Assistants, each giving a different set-up and a unique ability.
     The League of Extraordinary Explorers, double sized cards that can be purchased for 8 prestige points and exposed in the Main Gallery, these cards also have a unique ability.
     The Solo mode.
     Discard Tiles, for placing cards in a player's storage.
     Extra Cards: 5 Expert cards, 3 Favour cards, 4 Headline cards, 12 Patron cards 


About the game:
It’s the turn of the 20th century, the golden age of museums. As interest in and accessibility of museums grew exponentially, many institutions underwent an intense period of expansion on both an intellectual and physical level, searching to grow their collections for profit and science.

You play as a curator of one such museum and it’s your job to build the biggest, most coherent collection that you can in this game of collection and bartering featuring over 300 individual illustrations by Vincent Dutrait and authentic architectural facts. But it’s no simple task!

Each player in Museum has a small collection of relics to get them started, after which, they will have to send explorers around the world to uncover others. These relics each have a value which is either the cost to add them to your museum, or how much they contribute towards adding other relics to your museum. “Spent” Relics are added to your reserve. You can withdraw them from it by exchanging them for an equal amount of items however your opponents also has access to your reserve!

During the game you will be required to assemble different collections. These can be from different categories (war, agriculture, architecture, etc) or periods (Ancient Egypt, Rome, Aztec, etc). Patron cards will give you bonus cards for amassing certain collections. Explorer cards will allow you to hire famous archeologists to confer bonuses to your museum and event cards will provide you with some game changing circumstances that you’ll have to work around, based on historical events!

All these different elements make compiling your collection an interesting and sometimes tricky experience! At the end of the game points are scored based on collections and their value and the player with the most points wins!

Name: Pakutto Puritto (パクッとプリッと)
Museum: The World's Fair
Description:
Museum: The World's Fair introduces two new mechanisms to Museum.

The first new mechanism is the 'Pavilion' which introduces new shared objectives.

The second new mechanism is 'Loans.' Loans allow you to send an item to another player's museum which will benefit both of you. This is not available in the two player game.

The World's Fair expansion also includes three tower boards as well as additional events, personnel, and character cards.

—description from the publisher

Name: Panzer (Second Edition): C3i #28 Scenarios
Description:
Two scenarios for the Panzer Second Edition Game:

Scenario C3i-3: Treads over Dedushka: Estonia, 25 July 1944.

Scenario C3i-4: House of Soviets: Stalingrad, 30 September 1942.

Name: Museum: The Cthulhu Relics
Description:
Our intrepid archaeologists have stumbled upon lost relics infused with the power of 6 Old Ones (one for each Domain in the game). These artefacts will now be corrupting your continent decks and have a chance to appear as cards are drawn. On top of their standard value and a domain, each object has a power that varies depending on which god it’s dedicated to. You can use these powers to bolster your museum's Domain Collections or hamper your rivals.

That’s not all however. Possessing these relics will cause you to earn “Occult” points. The player with the most Occult points at the end of game will score bonus victory points. On top of that, as soon as you gain 6 Occult points, you get to draw a “Disciple of the Occult” secret objective card (much like your Patron card) which will give you a chance to score even more points at the end of the game! Sounds good right? But beware, the Old One’s power comes at a price…

Playing the most powerful relics of a value of 5 will attract the eye of the terrifying beings that linger behind the veil of reality, with calamitous effects for your museum. These cards act as a sort of double-edged sword. Using Dagon's most powerful relic for example will flood your opponents' galleries, rending parts of them unusable. However, the Old One will return to take his due, and some of your gallery space will also disappear into the depths...

The expansion contains over 40 new components, including object, character, Notoriety and Event cards as well as some different effects tokens, all contained within its own expansion box.

—description from the publisher

Name: Pokémon TCG: Mysterious Treasures Expansion
Description:
Mysterious Treasures is an English-language expansion roughly corresponding to the contemporaneous Japanese-language expansion Secret of the Lakes.

The expansion includes 124 cards.

—user summary

Name: Szabla i Krew
Description:
Saber & Blood is an exciting mix of a card game and a board game. Each player commands a band of three characters that fight each other in a vicious battle to the last drop of blood. Players control their characters on the board by playing cards from their unique decks of cards. Each faction has its own deck, character abilities, playing styles, strengths, and weaknesses that must be used strategically in order to defeat its opponents.  Fighting in the game is performed by using custom fencing stance dice secretly chosen by each of the opponents, aiming to outsmart each other by choosing the more advantageous fencing style. Play the right cards, move your characters to the best positions on the board, use your opponent's weakness to your advantage, chose the advantageous fencing style, and claim your victory with SABER AND BLOOD.

—description from the publisher

Name: Round of Fire
Description: Round of Fire is a generic miniature system with an innovative initiative management. With the basic rulebook you can play modern, near future and post-apocalypse battles, but you will find all you need to play every historical and even fantasy setting. Units are at single man and squad level and you can play with your favorite 6/15/20/28mm miniatures.

—user summary

Name: Cults of Dagon
Description:
Cults of Dagon is a print and play game of set collection and insanity for 2 to 4 players. The game is a work of fan fiction based on H. P. Lovecraft's story Dagon. The game is distributed for free, and anyone who is interested in playing it is allowed to make a copy for themselves and their friends.

In Cults of Dagon players control groups groups of 5 cultists traveling around the world to seek the knowledge and tools to summon the sea god Dagon. The tricky part is that too much knowledge may lead them to insanity, reducing their effectiveness for the rest of the game.

Each turn 6 cards are drawn from a deck of artifact cards. Each card represents a type of artifact (book, map, dagger, etc) and has a numerical value between 1 and 6. Players alternate placing their cultists on the cards. They cannot place cultists where they already have a presence, and must outbid by at least one the player with majority on an occupied card.

Once all cultists have been assigned, each card goes to the player with majority. The cards are arranged in sets (books with books, etc), and if the numerical value of a set reaches or exceeds the Insanity Value for that game, a cultist of that player goes insane and is removed from the game. The set that went bust is turned face down.

The game continues until the deck runs out of cards or a player loses 3 cultists. Players score the value of their face up cards. Each face down set is worth the Insanity Value of the game, regardless of card values.
Highest score wins the game.

The game contains two mini expansions: Dark Visions, and Devious Plots.

—description from the publisher

The expansion includes 98 cards.

Name: Wars of the Roses
Description:
This is a strategic level wargame on the 15th century English civil wars. The game system is identical to Taiheiki.

Players manage either the House of Lancaster or the House of York. 
Each leader counter represents historical kings, royalties and lords such Richard of York, Henry VI and Richard Neville. They affect battle, recruitment and area control.
During each turn, players move alternately their units based on initiative. After all movement is ended, battles are resolved, area control is determined and new armies are raised.

Victory is determined by victory points, gained mostly from area control.

Counters: 90 1.3cm/0.51 inch
Map: half standard map
Time: a year (15 turns)
Game area: all of Britain (excluding northern Scotland)


Issue game of Game Journal  #65

Name: Space Conquest
Description:
Object of this game is to conquer as many constellations (groups of stars) as you can.  You conquer a constellation when you get your colored discs on more than have the number of stars in the constellation.

Play takes place on a 34" x 22" mat with images of the constellations.  Players roll dice to move their pieces around the track on the outside.  You either stop on spaces with color\star combinations that allow you to put a marker on a star or stars in a constellation or you land on spaces that allow you to take a card and follow the instructions on the card.

Two other variations of game play include The Game of Polaris (The North Star) in which players start in a different constellation and move towards Polaris.  Final variations include a Fast Game Variation which allows you to just conquer stars based on dice throw instead of moving around the track on the game mat.

—user summary

Name: Unicorns & Zombies
Description:
In the bleak, war-torn landscape of the not-too-distant future, a battle rages on. On one side, an army of the undead: former friends and family members who have succumbed to the zombie virus — decaying flesh and an insatiable appetite for destruction are all that remain. On the other side, a magic squad of unicorns: pixie dust and rainbow farts, their mythical horns as deadly as their enchanting glare. Which side will you fight for? Which will fight against you?

Unicorns & Zombies is a turn-based card game for 2-4 players which pits — you guessed it —unicorns against zombies. Players draw a trio of cards — weapons, gear, or action — and equip their fighter in the hopes of taking out the opposing teammate(s). Some cards can make your fighter nearly invincible. Others can make you want to flip the table over and rage-quit. You won’t though, because winning is more important than keeping friends. In groups of 3 or more, the fighter you pull is completely random, so your love of unicorns could be totally useless when you’re forced to fight as a zombie. And sometimes, you’re the only fighter of your kind on the table, so you’ll need to be strategic AF to win the round.

—description from the designer

Name: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game – The Wilds of Rhovanion
Description:
"Dwarves had not passed that way for many years, but Gandalf had, and he knew how evil and danger had grown and thriven in the Wild, since the dragons had driven men from the lands, and the goblins had spread in secret after the battle of the Mines of Moria. Even the good plans of wise wizards like Gandalf and of good friends like Elrond go astray sometimes when you are off on dangerous adventures over the Edge of the Wild…"
—The Hobbit

Journey to the dangerous Wilderlands in the seventh deluxe expansion for The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game, The Wilds of Rhovanion!

Three new scenarios draw you north along the mighty river Anduin, through Mirkwood, and to the prosperous city of Dale. Throughout your adventures, you will find yourself faced with dangers lurking in every shadow as you struggle to protect a band of refugees who have escaped the grasp of Mordor and now seek asylum in the kingdom of Rhovanion. Battle Goblins and ravenous Spiders, explore Deep caverns, and ensure the safety of those you have sworn to protect!

—description from the publisher

This deluxe expansion will be supported by the "Ered Mithrin Cycle" of adventure packs.
Families: Collectible: Living Card Game (Fantasy Flight Games)
Game: The Lord of the Rings – The Card Game (LCG)

Name: First Martians: Extra ROI Tiles Promo
Description:
This mini expansion for First Martians: Adventures on the Red Planet board game includes two Ring 1, two Ring 2 and one Ring 3 new, extra tiles to enhance your Mars experinece!

Ring 1 ROI tiles are: Utopia Planitia & Moreux Crater. They allow you to gather samples, find new Points of Interest, but at a cost of paying additional energy cost or re-rolling your action dice.

Ring 2 ROI tiles are: Arabia Terra & Pavonis Mons. They allow you to get even more samples, but a similar costs.

Ring 3 ROI tile is Kasei Valles. It allows you to gather samples and even have an adventure while doing so!

Name: Escape
Description:
The gameboard is divided into 10x10 squares, representing a castle and surrounded by a moat.  Walls between some squares create a Pacman-style maze.  Two players, red and blue, race to move their tokens around the maze from the eight start squares of their color to the "ESCAPE" symbol at the drawbridge.

UK Registered Design â„– 839,010.

Name: Leap Frog Globe Game
Description:
This is an educational geography game for children that features an inflatable globe. There are three levels of play.

Game One is a simple picture matching activity with race element. Players attempt to match the picture on a card (like a Kangaroo) with a location on the globe (like Australia) as a timer is running. First player to the finish space wins.

Game Two is a race across the board as players attempt to match pictures and locations to a continent card (Asia, Africa, etc.) that was randomly assigned at the beginning of the session.

Game Three adds word cards and requires additional reading skills. This is also a race but it includes a card taking mechanic based on a word search between player's hands.

Designed for 2, 3, or 4 players age 3 or older.

Includes the inflatable globe, a globe stand, tokens, cards, timer, instruction booklet, and board.

Name: Small World: Power Pack 2
Description:
Will you choose the poor Cursed Fauns or the mighty Aquatic Priestesses for your next conquests?

Small World: Power Pack 2 includes all eight races and ten special powers from Cursed!, Grand Dames of Small World, and the Royal Bonus expansions, along with a tray to store all the tokens.

—description from the publisher

Name: Small World: Power Pack 1
Description:
Will you choose the fearless Lava Barbarians or the glorious Catapult Ice Witches for your next conquest?

Small World: Power Pack 1 includes all eight races and eight special powers from the Be Not Afraid... and A Spider's Web expansions for Small World, along with a tray to store all the tokens.

—description from the publisher

Name: Pokémon TCG: Pokémon Card VS Expansion
Description:
User Summary

Pokémon Card VS - ãƒã‚±ãƒ¢ãƒ³ã‚«ãƒ¼ãƒ‰â˜…VS is a Japanese-language expansion; it has no corresponding English-language expansion.

The expansion includes 151 cards.

The VS expansion was distributed in a non-conventional manner. While the cards were still packaged in foil packs, each of these packs contained 30 cards instead of the traditional 10 cards. This was also the first time the term 'half deck' was officially used and became a recognized method of gameplay. There were three random half decks released: Grass & Lightning - è‰ é›·ãƒãƒ¼ãƒ•ãƒ‡ãƒƒã‚­, Water & Fire - æ°´ç‚Žãƒãƒ¼ãƒ•ãƒ‡ãƒƒã‚­, and Fighting & Psychic - é—˜è¶…ãƒãƒ¼ãƒ•ãƒ‡ãƒƒã‚­. Each half deck contained a random assortment of set type Pokémon (i.e. one could only get a Fire-type Pokémon in the Water & Fire half deck). Colorless-type Pokémon and Trainer cards could be found in all half decks.

The 30 cards in each booster pack consisted of: 11 energy cards, 11 character cards, 6 trainer cards (2 of which were TMs), 1 holo character card, and 1 holo special energy card.

Wizards of the Coast officially stated that they had no plans to release the VS set, primarily because they had competitive play in mind. Some cards from this expansion were still released in English in the Tyranitar Half Deck; however, these cards were produced by MEDIAFACTORY and received a limited release to competitors of the 2001 Tropical Mega Battle. Despite this statement, Pokémon USA localized the Generation IV equivalent, Pokémon SP when they debuted in the Platinum expansion.

-- summary obtained from:  https://leonhartopedia.fandom.com/wiki/Pok%C3%A9mon_VS_(TCG)

Name: Lost To Time
Description:
Lost To Time is a real-time co-operative board game in which players must collect 4 keys to unlock the door leading to the unimaginable treasure. It is played in 10 real-time minutes with the possibility of gaining additional time as you play by rolling a set of dice and taking actions simultaneously. Players will use these actions to create a network of paths leading to all corners of the gameboard and travel on them to collect 4 Golden Keys. But, watch out! There are deadly traps along the way. If that wasn't enough, the ceiling is collapsing and giant blocks of stone are coming down to crush you.

Players will have to be quick and smart about making strategic decisions all while trying to survive! Run fast, help each other, and don't die!

—description from the publisher

Name: Rock'n Rodeo: The Shufflettes
Description:
The Shufflettes is a promo for the German board game Rock'n Rodeo.

The Shufflettes are a fictional band consisting of members of the German blog erklaerpeer.de. They are a Local Band and you can book them for 5K.

—user summary

Name: Tens Solitaire
Description:
Tens Solitaire is a quick solitaire game using a standard deck of 52 cards. Players remove pairs of card adding up to ten. Tens, Jacks, Queens, and Kings are removed in sets of four matching cards.

13 cards are dealt in two rows of five cards and one row of 3 cards. Remaining cards for a draw pile.

You may discard any pair of cards which add up to 10 or any set of four matching face cards or tens. Replace all discarded cards from the top of the draw pile.

You win the game if you can get all 52 cards on the table.

Name: Världsregeringen: Valfläsk
Description: This expansion replaces the six original cards that are used during the "Ärendefasen" with new versions that give more strategic options for the players. The expansion also makes it possible for up six players.

Name: Chrononauts: German Cake Promo Card
Description:
This special Artifact card was designed to work in original Chrononauts, but you can use it in EAC by house rule agreement before the games starts.

When used with EAC, since the TimeLine is totally different, it is freely playable, and also counts as a dessert food item for 4 Missions.

Text says:
"Cannot be played or stolen if [Hitler is alive]. Once in play, it can be discarded at any time and used as a Memo. Cannot be used to stop theft of cake with Get There First." (I.e. it can't be used up to prevent itself from being stolen)

This card debuted as a promo card at Dragon*Con 2002, but was added to the original game during the 3rd printing.
It was also available for purchase by itself from the Looney Labs webstore

Name: Chrononauts: Beatles Reunion Album Promo Card
Description:
Can be added to Chrononauts or Early American Chrononauts.

Text says:
"The card can not be played or stolen unless flipped.
If not flipped, a Beatles Reunion CD in play may be substituted for any one artifact listed on your mission"

Originally included in Fluxx Blanxx, but was added to the original game version 1.4.  It was also available by itself from Looney Labs webstore

Name: Chrononauts: Teeny Tiny Time Machine Promo Card
Description:
This Gadget works in either type of Chrononauts deck.

Text says:
"If you have this Gadget on the table, any Inverter you play works like a Reverse Fate. You may only use one Time Machine action per turn."

It debuted as a promo card at GenCon 2004, and was added to the original game during the 3rd printing.
It was also available for purchase by itself from the Looney Labs webstore

Name: Chrononauts: Really Fast Time Machine Promo Card
Description:
This Gadget works in either type of Chrononauts deck.

Text says:
"If you have this Gadget on the table, you may play an extra Inverter or Patch, and draw to replace it, after your normal turn action. You may only use one Time Machine action per turn."

It debuted as a promo card at Origins 2004, and was added to the original game during the 3rd printing.
It was also available for purchase by itself from the Looney Labs webstore

Name: Battle of Heroes: Myth Taken
Description:
A quick combat squad game of 3 units each, where you see which mythological characters can best each other in battle (Egyptian and Greek currently, with more planned for the future).

No Dice. No Cards. No luck. Just pure strategy and choosing different team combinations.

Every turn, the player progresses each of their unit's turn meter (by moving the respective cube along the ready track) until they have a unit ready to attack. Each Hero has special abilities and attacks, creating an interesting strategy to every team. Each ability has a value (either damage, heal or alter turn meter) that the player activates and chooses to target.

Players win by defeating all of their opponents units.

Alternatively, more than 2 players can fight in a free for all, where each player is out for themselves.

Print and Play is available ahead of an upcoming crowdfunding campaign
